metadata.case_name: Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate represented by Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha v. Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate

facts.text: Dr. K. Banerjee appointed as Assistant Medical Officer of Dimakuchi Tea Estate with effect from November 1, 1950, subject to satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

Appointment letter stated that during probation, suitability for permanent employment would be considered; if unsuitable, seven days' notice terminating appointment; if guilty of misconduct, instant dismissal; if suitable at end, confirmed in service.
In February 1951, Dr. Banerjee given increment of Rs. 5 per mensem.
On April 21, 1951, manager Mr. Booth terminated Dr. Banerjee's services effective April 22, 1951, with one month's salary in lieu of notice; no reasons given initially.
Dr. Banerjee inquired reasons; reply stated reasons on medical side known to Dr. Cox, main reason deceitful addition of figures to medical indent after signed by Dr. Cox.

Manager later stated discharge on ground of incompetence in medical duties; Dr. Cox found incompetent, lacking knowledge of microscopical and laboratory work; gave faulty quinine injection to Mr. Peacock causing severe illness nearly paralysing leg.
Cause espoused by Mangaldai Circle of Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha; secretary wrote to manager inquiring reasons.
Conciliation proceedings held unsuccessfully over termination.
Matter referred to Tripartite Appellate Board (Labour Commissioner Assam, reps of Indian Tea Association and Chah Karmachari Sangha); recommended reinstatement from date of discharge.
Management offered 28 months salary in lieu of reinstatement; appellants did not agree.
Dr. Banerjee received Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left tea garden.

Government of Assam notified reference on December 23, 1953 under s.10(1)(c) Industrial Disputes Act to Shri U.K. Gohain, Tribunal: Whether management justified in dismissing Dr. K.P. Banerjee? If not, entitled to reinstatement or other relief?
Tribunal held Dr. Banerjee not a workman, no industrial dispute, no jurisdiction.
Labour Appellate Tribunal affirmed: dispute must be between employers and workmen.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on March 14, 1956, limited to whether dispute re non-workman falls within s.2(k).

legal_issues.text: Whether a dispute in relation to the termination of service of Dr. K.P. Banerjee, who is not a workman within the meaning of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, falls within the scope of the definition of 'industrial dispute' in s.2(k).

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'of any person' in third part of s.2(k) is of wide import, not equated to 'any workman'; dispute between employer and workmen connected with non-employment of Dr. Banerjee (non-workman) is industrial dispute.

Limitations on 'any person': real/substantial dispute where relief possible; relates to same establishment; person is employee discharged/in service/candidate; workmen have nexus via personal/general labour interest.

respondent_arguments.text: Dr. Banerjee not a workman; dispute not between employers and workmen, hence not industrial dispute; Tribunal no jurisdiction.
'Any person' limited to persons with community of interest to workmen, i.e., workmen class including discharged/future workmen.

court_reasoning.text: S.2(k) analysed into three parts: dispute/difference; between employers/employers, employers/workmen, workmen/workmen; connected with employment/non-employment/terms/conditions of labour of any person. 'Any person' not unlimited; must read in context of Act's scheme for workmen.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act regulates employer-workmen relations; distinguishes workmen from supervisory staff.

court_reasoning.text: Objects: promote amity between employer/workmen; settle disputes between specified parties; prevent strikes/lock-outs; relief to workmen on lay-off/retrenchment; collective bargaining.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Awards binding on parties, successors, all employed/subsequently employed workmen (s.18).

court_reasoning.text: Literal 'any person' leads to absurdities (e.g., dispute over District Magistrate's employment); limitations: real dispute capable of relief; relates to establishment; 'any person' means one with direct/substantial interest/community of interest to workmen class.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dr. Banerjee supervisory/medical staff, no community of interest with workmen.

court_reasoning.text: 'Any person' wider than 'workman' to include discharged workmen pre-1956; not all employees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Workmen not directly/substantially interested in supervisory staff's terms.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J. (separate): Words 'any person' plain/ordinary meaning includes non-workmen; no valid restriction to 'workman class'; other sections/context do not limit; Act preserves industrial peace, benefits incidental.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dissenting on majority view but appeal dismissed per majority.

holdings.text: Dispute regarding non-workman (Dr. Banerjee) not industrial dispute under s.2(k) unless parties (workmen) have direct/substantial interest/community of interest therein; here, no such interest as he is supervisory staff.

precedents_cited.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Disputes re reinstatement/dismissal of discharged workmen are industrial disputes; 'any person' includes discharged workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Any person' limited by community of interest; workmen not interested in arbitrary dismissals without direct link.

precedents_cited.case_name: Newspapers Ltd. v. State Industrial Tribunal, U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual dispute espoused by union becomes industrial dispute.
Supported wide 'any person' but concerned discharged workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S.N. Modak
East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of industrial dispute and workman; reference/adjudication; binding nature of awards; scheme limits 'any person' to those with workmen community of interest.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed holding dispute over termination of Dr. Banerjee (non-workman, supervisory staff) not an industrial dispute under s.2(k) as workmen lacked direct/substantial interest/community of interest.

key_quotes.text: 'Any person' in s.2(k) means a person in whose employment, non-employment etc., the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest-with whom they have a community of interest.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding limiting scope of industrial dispute.

key_quotes.text: The Act is primarily meant for regulating the relations of employers and workmen-past, present and future. It draws a distinction between workmen as such and the managerial or supervisory staff.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Dr. K.P. Banerjee was not a workman. He belonged to the medical or technical staff-a different category altogether from workmen.
key_quotes.speaker: court
